metadata.title: Maxent Model and Named Entity Recognition

data.text:
We surveyed cancer types from 569 patients in a cancer hospital and found the gender distribution of patients who have and don't have hodgkins lymphoma. What is the joint probability P(female, lymphoma) and conditional probability P(female|lymphoma)?


LymphomaNo Lymphoma
Male59230
Female10270

option.explanation: Correct!
Make sure that you have the right numerators for both probabilities.
The denominator for the conditional probability is the number of people who have lymphoma
The denominator for the joint probability is the total number of patients

data.text:
We surveyed cancer types from 502 patients in a cancer hospital and found the gender distribution of patients who have and don't have hodgkins lymphoma. What is the joint probability P(female, lymphoma) and conditional probability P(female|lymphoma)?

data.text:
In the maxent model, we've learned that P(c|d,λ) = expΣλifi(c,d)/ΣexpΣλifi(c',d). This equation is also in the lecture slide #25. Given the 3 classes and the 3 features, compute the following probabilities. wi = "Goéric"

  • P(PERSON | by Goéric) =
  • P(LOCATION | by Goéric) =
  • P(DRUG | by Goéric) =

WeightFeature
 1.8f1(c, d) = [c = LOCATION & wi-1 = in & isCapitalized(wi)]
-0.6f2(c, d) = [c = LOCATION & hasAccentedLatinChar(wi)]
 0.3f3(c, d) = [c = DRUG & ends(wi, c)]
data.explanation:
• P(PERSON | by Goéric) = e0 / (e0 + e-0.6 + e0.3) = 0.34
  • P(LOCATION | by Goéric) = e-0.6 / (e0 + e-0.6 + e0.3) = 0.19
  • P(DRUG | by Goéric) = e0.3 / (e0 + e-0.6 + e0.3) = 0.47

option.explanation: Correct!
f<sub>1</sub> must not be counted towards P(LOCATION | by Goéric) because Goéric is not preceded by "in".
f<sub>2</sub> must be only counted towards the class LOCATION due to its condition, c = LOCATION.
f<sub>1</sub> must not be counted towards P(DRUG| by Goéric) because Goéric is not preceded by "in".

data.text:
In the maxent model, we've learned that P(c|d,λ) = expΣλifi(c,d)/ΣexpΣλifi(c',d). This equation is also in the lecture slide #25. Given the 3 classes and the 3 features, compute the following probabilities. wi = "Goéric"

  • P(PERSON | by Goéric) =
  • P(LOCATION | by Goéric) =
  • P(DRUG | by Goéric) =

WeightFeature
 1.2f1(c, d) = [c = LOCATION & wi-1 = in & isCapitalized(wi)]
-0.3f2(c, d) = [c = LOCATION & hasAccentedLatinChar(wi)]
 0.4f3(c, d) = [c = DRUG & ends(wi, c)]
data.explanation:
• P(PERSON | by Goéric) = e0 / (e0 + e-0.3 + e0.4) = 0.31
  • P(LOCATION | by Goéric) = e-0.3 / (e0 + e-0.3 + e0.4) = 0.23
  • P(DRUG | by Goéric) = e0.4 / (e0 + e-0.3 + e0.4) = 0.46

option.explanation: Correct!
f<sub>1</sub> must not be counted towards P(LOCATION | by Goéric) because Goéric is not preceded by "in".
f<sub>2</sub> must be only counted towards the class LOCATION due to its condition, c = LOCATION.
f<sub>1</sub> must not be counted towards P(DRUG| by Goéric) because Goéric is not preceded by "in".

data.text:
In the maxent model, we've learned that P(c|d,λ) = expΣλifi(c,d)/ΣexpΣλifi(c',d). This equation is also in the lecture slide #25. Given the 3 classes and the 3 features, compute the following probabilities. wi = "Goéric"

  • P(PERSON | by Goéric) =
  • P(LOCATION | by Goéric) =
  • P(DRUG | by Goéric) =

WeightFeature
 1.5f1(c, d) = [c = LOCATION & wi-1 = in & isCapitalized(wi)]
-0.5f2(c, d) = [c = LOCATION & hasAccentedLatinChar(wi)]
 0.7f3(c, d) = [c = DRUG & ends(wi, c)]
data.explanation:
• P(PERSON | by Goéric) = e0 / (e0 + e-0.5 + e0.7) = 0.28
  • P(LOCATION | by Goéric) = e-0.5 / (e0 + e-0.5 + e0.7) = 0.17
  • P(DRUG | by Goéric) = e0.7 / (e0 + e-0.5 + e0.7) = 0.56

option.explanation: Correct!
f<sub>1</sub> must not be counted towards P(LOCATION | by Goéric) because Goéric is not preceded by "in".
f<sub>2</sub> must be only counted towards the class LOCATION due to its condition, c = LOCATION.
f<sub>1</sub> must not be counted towards P(DRUG| by Goéric) because Goéric is not preceded by "in".

data.text:
We have defined three classes {PERSON, LOCATION, other} and five features like the following. We have also hand-labeled a sentence to train a NER classifier. Each word is labeled in the format of {word}/{class} (e.g. Obama/PER). Compute the sum of the empirical expectations of all features for the following sentence. The empirical expectation of a feature is $$ \Sigma_{(c,d)\in observed(C,D)} f_i(c,d)$$

President/O Obama/PER met/O with/O former/O President/O George/PER H.W./PER Bush/PER and/O former/O Florida/LOC Gov./O Jeb/PER Bush/PER in/O the/O Oval/LOC Office/LOC on/O Friday,/O joining/O in/O a/O bipartisan/O gathering/O in/O an/O election/O year./O

Features
f1(c, d) = [c = LOCATION & isCapitalized(wi)]
f2(c, d) = [c = LOCATION & classOf(wi-1) = LOCATION]
f3(c, d) = [c = PERSON & isCapitalized(wi)]
f4(c, d) = [c = PERSON & classOf(wi-1) = PERSON]
f5(c, d) = [c = PERSON & wi-1 = "President" ]
data.explanation:
See the slide #14-17

$$empirical E(f_1) = 3 $$

$$empirical E(f_2) = 1 $$

$$empirical E(f_3) = 6 $$

$$empirical E(f_4) = 3 $$

$$empirical E(f_5) = 2 $$

option.explanation: Correct!

data.text:
We have defined three classes {PERSON, LOCATION, other} and five features like the following. We have also hand-labeled a sentence to train a NER classifier. Each word is labeled in the format of {word}/{class} (e.g. Obama/PER). Compute the sum of the empirical expectations of all features for the following sentence. The empirical expectation of a feature is $$ \Sigma_{(c,d)\in observed(C,D)} f_i(c,d)$$

President/O Obama/PER met/O with/O former/O President/O George/PER H.W./PER Bush/PER and/O former/O Florida/LOC Gov./O Jeb/PER Bush/PER in/O the/O Oval/LOC Office/LOC on/O Friday,/O joining/O in/O a/O bipartisan/O gathering/O in/O an/O election/O year./O

Features
f1(c, d) = [c = LOCATION & isCapitalized(wi)]
f2(c, d) = [c = LOCATION & classOf(wi-1) = LOCATION]
f3(c, d) = [c = PERSON & wi-1 = "Gov."]
f4(c, d) = [c = PERSON & wi-1 = "President"]
f5(c, d) = [c = PERSON & isCapitalized(wi) ]
data.explanation:
See the slide #14-17

$$empirical E(f_1) = 3 $$

$$empirical E(f_2) = 1 $$

$$empirical E(f_3) = 1 $$

$$empirical E(f_4) = 2 $$

$$empirical E(f_5) = 6 $$

option.explanation: Correct!

data.text:
We've built an NER system and ran it on a tiny dataset. Based on the following result, compute the F1 score of the system. (round to the 3 decimal places, e.g. 0.123)

GOLD PERSONGOLD other
SYSTEM GUESS PERSON2033
SYSTEM GUESS other104
data.explanation:
Precision: % of selected items that are correct
Recall: % of correct items that are selected
F1: 2PR/(P+R)

Precision: 20 / 53 = 0.377
Recall: 20 / 30 = 0.667
F1: (2 * 0.377 * 0.677) / (0.377 + 0.677) = 0.482

option.explanation: Correct!

data.text:

Precision: 15 / 19 = 0.789
Recall: 15 / 33 = 0.455
F1: (2 * 0.789 * 0.455) / (0.789 + 0.455) = 0.577

data.text:
We've built an NER system and ran it on a tiny dataset. Based on the following result, compute the F1 score of the system. (round to the 3 decimal places, e.g. 0.123)

GOLD PERSONGOLD other
SYSTEM GUESS PERSON2010
SYSTEM GUESS other1114
data.explanation:
Precision: % of selected items that are correct
Recall: % of correct items that are selected
F1: 2PR/(P+R)

Precision: 20 / 30 = 0.667
Recall: 20 / 31 = 0.645
F1: (2 * 0.667 * 0.645) / (0.667 + 0.645) = 0.656

option.explanation: Correct!

data.text: Suppose we build a maxent classifier over 5 classes {PERSON, ORGANIZATION, LOCATION, PRODUCT, OTHER}. Suppose further that for a particular data item, one feature matches for the class PERSON with its lambda weight as $$\ln4$$. No other features match that particular data item for any other class. What will be the probability of the class PERSON on this data item at classification time? (numerical response rounded to the nearest tenths, e.g. 0.1 or 0.9)
data.explanation:
For the particular data item, the vote for the class PERSON is ln4 and the votes for the other classes are 0. Thus, the probability of the class PERSON on this data item is like the following:

$$\frac{e^{ln4}}{e^{ln4}+e^{0}+e^{0}+e^{0}+e^{0}} = \frac{4}{4+1+1+1+1} = 0.5$$

option.explanation: Correct!
